moves.1. h3: This game was a slow, positional affair. The Pawn position got locked in place and made for few opportunities to attack, but some sharp tactics enabled me to get a small advantage and eventually exploit it for a difficult win.
moves.1... e5: I respond to White's unusual opening by trying to seize the center.
moves.2. e4 Nf6 3. d3 d5 4. Qe2: This move surprised me. White's development will be slowed a little.
moves.4... d4 5. c3 c5: I'm thinking I might be able to get a positional advantage by controlling more space.
moves.6. b3 Nc6 7. Bb2 Be6 8. Qc2: I thought White would play Nb2 here and prepare to castle, but he prefers a slower style of development. Wilhelm Steinitz used such a style to great success, so it can work -- but only in a relatively closed position.
moves.8... Be7 9. g3 O-O: My own development is now complete. I have a slight edge in space, so my objective will be to try and keep White cramped.
moves.10. Bg2 b5 11. a3 a5 12. Nf3 h6: In keeping with the cramping principle. White's Knight cannot now venture to g5.
moves.14... b4 15. c4 Qd7 16. g4 Nh7: When one has an advantage in space, one should try and deny the opponent threats. Retreating pieces to prevent the opponent from freeing his game is acceptable, per Znosko-Borovsky.
moves.17. a4 f6 18. Nh2 g6: Now all of White's pieces are on his 1st or 2nd rank. I have 3 pieces past my 2nd rank and 2 advanced Pawns helping to keep White cramped. It's time to start squeezing the life out of White's position.
moves.19. f3 f5: If a file opens, it'll be to my advantage, as I am in more of a position to attack.
moves.20. Rf2 fxe4 21. fxe4 Rxf2 22. Kxf2 Rf8+: Now I have control of the only open file, augmenting my positional advantage.
moves.23. Ndf3: A self-pin. If I were in White's position, I would have preferred 23 Ke2 to be followed by 24 Rf1, disputing Black's control of the file.
moves.23... Ng5: I pile on. White should move his King to unpin his Knight.
moves.24. Qe2 Nxf3 25. Bxf3 h5: The pin will cause White to lose material if he lets it stand. 26 Kg1! is called for.
moves.26. Kg2: Unpinning, but now the Bishop can't move. If White had played Kg1, his Bishop would now be mobile.
moves.26... Be7 27. Rg1 Bg5 28. Bc1 Bxc1 29. R: White's g-pawn is now fixed as a target.
moves.31. Rh1 Ne7 32. Qd2 Rf4: Black's own g-pawn is shielded from attack.
moves.33. Qe2 Ng6 34. Kf1 Nh4: The threat is ...Nxf3 Nxf3 Bxg4, creating a passed Pawn for Black.
moves.35. Ke1 Nxf3+ 36. Nxf3 Bxg4: Not only is Black up a Pawn, White's Knight is now pinned as well. Too many pins to overcome -- the danger of a cramped, immobile position.
moves.37. Rf1 Qf7 38. Rf2 Bxf3 39. Qf1: Now I'm up a piece and a Pawn. If I can exchange off the heavy artillery, the endgame should be an easy win.
moves.39... Bxe4: If White plays 40 dxe4??? the follow-up is 40...Rxe2 41 Qxe2 Qxe2 42 Kxe2 Ke7 and White can resign, as the King-and-Pawn ending is hopeless. White must keep at least 1 major piece on the board to have any chance of drawing.
moves.40. Rxf4 Qxf4: White's only chance is to move his Queen. 41 Qh3 is probably the best move.
moves.41. Qxf4 gxf4: Game over. The King-and-Pawn ending is easy to win.
White resigns, as Black's d-pawn Queens in 2 moves.
